title: Investors sceptical as AMP bets house on ambitious turnaround
text:
“But anything that provides clarity around strategy will be well received by the investment community and I think clarity around remediation will provide relief.”

Over the course of eleven separate announcements AMP revealed a first half loss of $2.3 billion, a $650 million capital raising and the revival of the life insurance business sale to Resolution Life for $3 billion.

AMP CEO Francesco De Ferrari is betting the house on an ambitious plan to save the wealth management company. Janie Barrett

Allan Gray chief investment officer Simon Mawhinney said the result was encouraging but the prospect of a successful turnaround was far from certain. He also questioned the need to raise capital.

“We would have preferred them to dig into their $1.7 billion excess capital than to tap shareholders but it appears that many wanted this capital raising,” Mr Mawhinney said.

AMP will offer equity at $1.50 a share or a 13.3 per cent discount to the closing price on Wednesday. A book build with institutional investors was underway and retail investors will be given the opportunity to subscribe up to $15,000 worth of shares.

The company is betting on making $300 million in savings annually with $75 million coming from more efficient operations including job cuts, $50 million from a learner corporate structure and $175 million coming from simplification of its legacy business including aligned advisers.

AMP’s Mr De Ferrari said the company would have fewer advisers in the future and implied as many as 800 of its 2400 advisers could depart but declined to say it was targeting a specific number.

Advertisement

“It’s not going to be the number that counts it’s the quality of the advice” Mr De Ferrari said.

He said he was confident of getting the deal across the line after it was scuttled by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand last month, saying the company was having “constructive discussions” with the relevant regulators and “making significant progress”.

AMP has also picked a fight with the advisers it pays to sell its products by announcing it would no longer pay advisers four times earnings for advice businesses under the buyer of last resort or BOLR program.

The decision to raise $650 million in equity with the share price at record lows has also raised eyebrows. AMP shares were as high as $6 three years ago and closed at $1.73 before going into a trading halt on Thursday morning.

Mr De Ferrari defended the capital raising as necessary and said the new strategy would not be possible with the additional investment.

“That would have required a slowing of growth in the meantime and that was clearly not in the interest of shareholders and we think we are going to get very wide institutional support” Mr De Ferrari said.

AMP will invest up to $1.3 billion in the business over the next three years in its quest to reinvent itself and stake a claim over the customers the banks have abandoned.

“We want to invest to build the best wealth management business in Australia and we feel we can take a leadership position because everyone else is exiting” Mr De Ferrari said.

Staff numbers at the company were also on the rise mainly on account of additional hires in remediation teams and compliance with the number of FTEs rising from 5977 at this time last year to 6505.

“We don’t have the appropriate level of return for the risk we are taking on” Mr De Ferrari said.

AMP's chief financial officer-elect John Patrick Moorehead will leave the business as part of the shake-up. His deputy James Georgeson will be taking over from retiring CFO Gordon Leferve with the handover to begin immediately.
description: The financial advice company's ambitious plan to reinvent itself will need everything to go right.
